Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a common disease of apple trees caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It affects the appearance and quality of fruit, foliage, and can weaken the tree over time.
symptoms: Dark olive-green to brown spots on leaves
Scabby, dark lesions on fruit
Premature leaf drop
Twisted or puckered young leaves
treatment: Apply fungicides in early spring before infection occurs
Remove and destroy fallen leaves in autumn to reduce fungal spores
Prune trees to improve air circulation
prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties
Maintain proper tree spacing for good air circulation
Apply protective fungicide sprays according to local recommendations

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV) is a DNA virus from the family Geminiviridae that causes a devastating disease of tomato plants. It is transmitted by the whitefly Bemisia tabaci and can cause significant yield losses in tropical and subtropical regions.
symptoms: Leaves curl upward and appear smaller than normal
Leaflets show strong yellowing at margins and between veins
Plants appear stunted with a bushy appearance
Flowers may drop before fruit development
Significantly reduced fruit production
treatment: No direct cure exists once plants are infected
Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spread
Control whitefly populations using approved insecticides
Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies
Consider biological controls like parasitic wasps for whitefly management
prevention: Plant virus-resistant tomato varieties
Use physical barriers like row covers or fine mesh
Maintain a weed-free environment around the growing area
Establish tomato plantings upwind from other susceptible crops
Implement a crop-free period in areas with high disease pressure

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight of potato is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It is one of the most common foliar diseases of potatoes and can also affect tomatoes and other members of the Solanaceae family. The disease can cause significant yield reductions if not properly managed.
symptoms: Dark brown to black lesions with concentric rings (target spots)
Lesions first appear on lower, older leaves
Yellow areas surrounding the lesions
Lesions may coalesce, causing extensive leaf damage
Severely affected leaves may die but typically remain attached to the plant
treatment: Apply appropriate fungicides at the first sign of disease
Rotate between fungicide classes to prevent resistance
Ensure adequate plant nutrition, particularly potassium
Remove and destroy severely infected plant material
Improve air circulation through proper plant spacing
prevention: Use certified disease-free seed potatoes
Practice crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops
Maintain plant vigor through proper fertilization
Water at the base of plants and avoid overhead irrigation
Plant resistant or tolerant varieties when available

Corn___Common_rust.description: Common rust of corn is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi and occurs almost anywhere corn is grown. While rarely causing severe yield losses in field corn, it can significantly impact sweet corn production if infection occurs early in crop development.
symptoms: Small, round to elongated cinnamon-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces
Pustules rupture the epidermis and release powdery rust-colored spores
Pustules darken to black as the season progresses
Severe infections may cause leaf yellowing and premature death
Symptoms typically appear first on lower leaves
treatment: Apply registered fungicides if disease appears before tasseling
Time fungicide applications according to disease progression and weather forecasts
Ensure proper application coverage for effective control
Scout fields regularly to monitor disease development
Consider economics of treatment in field corn versus sweet corn
prevention: Plant rust-resistant corn hybrids
Avoid planting corn extremely early when cool, wet conditions are expected
Provide adequate plant nutrition to support plant health
Practice crop rotation where practical
Eliminate volunteer corn that may harbor the pathogen

Grape___Black_rot.description: Black rot is a fungal disease caused by Guignardia bidwellii that affects grapes worldwide, but is particularly problematic in warm, humid climates. It can cause complete crop loss in severe cases if left unmanaged.
symptoms: Small yellow spots on leaves that enlarge and turn brown with black borders
Black lesions on shoots, stems, and fruit stalks
Fruit initially shows light brown spots that rapidly encompass the entire berry
Infected berries shrivel and become hard black 'mummies' that remain attached to the cluster
Tiny black pycnidia (fungal fruiting bodies) develop in infected tissues
treatment: Apply appropriate fungicides beginning at early shoot growth
Continue fungicide applications on a 10-14 day schedule through veraison
Remove mummified berries from vines during winter pruning
Maintain an open canopy through proper pruning to aid fungicide penetration
Consider cultural practices like leaf removal around fruit clusters
prevention: Remove all mummies from the vineyard during dormant season
Cultivate soil beneath vines to bury mummies and reduce spore release
Practice good canopy management to improve air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation when possible
Plant less susceptible varieties in high-pressure areas

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani. It is one of the most common tomato diseases, affecting leaves, stems, and fruits of tomato plants.
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on lower/older leaves
Yellow areas surrounding the dark spots
Leaves turning yellow and falling off
Dark lesions on stems
treatment: Remove and destroy affected leaves immediately
Apply approved fungicides at first sign of disease
Avoid overhead watering to keep foliage dry
prevention: Use disease-free seeds and resistant varieties
Practice crop rotation (3-4 year cycle)
Stake plants for better air circulation
Apply organic mulch to prevent soil-splash onto leaves

Tomato___healthy.description: This is a healthy tomato plant showing no signs of disease or pest damage.
symptoms: No symptoms of disease
treatment: Continue regular maintenance and care
prevention: Regular monitoring for early detection of any issues
Proper watering, fertilization, and pruning practices
Maintain good air circulation around plants
